speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, he's doing it again!  Must this dog stare at me all the time?

speaker: Martin
text: I don't know.  Eddie - must ya? [_Eddie carries on staring_] Apparently he must.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Eddie:_] What is so fascinating about me?  What is it? Do you imagine I am a large piece of kibble?  Am I some sort of canine enigma?  Think about it, get back to me.

speaker: Daphne
text: Here we are, gents, dinner's up. [_to Martin:_] Can I give you a hand clearing up your papers?

speaker: Martin
text: No, you better let me.  I need to keep these in a particular order.

speaker: Daphne
text: What is all this, anyway?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it's an old case of mine from the police force - the "Weeping Lotus" murder.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I can't believe you're still trotting this old thing up. He's been trying to solve this case for twenty years.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, and I'm not stopping until I do solve it.  You adopt certain instincts when you're a cop.  And my instinct tells me that this case can be cracked.  There just must be one small thing I keep overlooking. [_tidies papers_]

speaker: Frasier
text: There is - who the murderer was. [_laughs_]  _The doorbell sounds and Frasier goes to answer it as Daphne and Martin chat._

speaker: Daphne
text: It's nice you feel so dedicated.

speaker: Martin
text: It's a hobby.  Some guys build a boat in their garage, I try to figure out why a maniac would kill a hooker and try to stuff her entire body into a bowling bag.  It's relaxing!  _At this point Frasier opens the front door to Niles who is carrying a bottle of wine.  He enters and hands the wine to Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Sorry I'm late, Frasier.  Just as we were leaving, Maris had a run-in with a rude directory assistance operator and it shattered her calm.

speaker: Frasier
text: Have you ever considered that maybe Maris is a bit high strung?  Maybe she should see someone.

speaker: Niles
text: She's seen everyone, why do you think she was calling directory assistance?

speaker: Daphne
text: Evening, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.  It's so good to see you again. [_she puts the meal down_] What an enchanting scent you're wearing.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_smells herself_] Must be the ranch dressing.  Won't Mrs. Crane be coming?

speaker: Niles
text: No, I'm afraid.  And please, no more of this "Doctor" and "Mrs. Crane" formality.  To you, it's Niles and... [_stumped_] er...

speaker: Frasier
text: Maris.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, Maris.

speaker: Martin
text: Glad you could join us, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I wouldn't have missed it.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I guess the food's all ready: why don't we just go ahead and start?  _Everyone sits down except Daphne who begins to take her food into the kitchen._

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, enjoy.

speaker: Martin
text: Where are you going?

speaker: Daphne
text: I thought I'd have mine in the kitchen.

speaker: Martin
text: Don't be ridiculous.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, we can't have you eating by yourself in the kitchen. I'll join you.

speaker: Martin
text: No.  We're all eating right here, like a family, end of discussion.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, isn't this nice?  Feels just like home.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm famished.

speaker: Frasier
text: Me, too.

speaker: Martin
text: You boys still say a prayer before you eat?  _They relent and pretend they do.  All four close their eyes and hold their hands together.  As Martin begins his prayer, Niles stares at Daphne as Eddie stares at Frasier.  Daphne does not notice with her eyes shut.  However, Frasier notices Eddie's skin-creeping look._

speaker: Martin
text: We thank you, Lord, for the food we're about to eat.  You have blessed our table with your palm.  And thank you, Lord, for bringing this family together and we also thank you for the other gifts you have given to us.  And may we always be able to share with those less fortunate...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Eddie:_] OH, WILL YOU STOP STARING!

speaker: Niles
text: [_off guard:_] I wasn't staring!

speaker: Martin
text: [_takes what he can get_] Amen.  _They all settle down.  Daphne looks at Niles a little suspiciously as he begins the meal conversation._

speaker: Niles
text: So Frasier, did you happen to read Derek Mann's column today?  You were mentioned.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I missed it.

speaker: Niles
text: Just as well, it wasn't flattering.

speaker: Frasier
text: I still would have liked to have seen it anyway.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, why didn't you say so? [_takes it out of his pocket_]

speaker: Daphne
text: If I may ask, who's Derek Mann?

speaker: Martin
text: He writes that "Mann About Town" column for the _Times_.  The things that guys comes out with, sometimes he's really funny - what did he say about you?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_reading:_] "I hate Frasier Crane."

speaker: Martin
text: [_laughs, then:_] Oh, sorry.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's it.  "I hate Frasier Crane."  That's it?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, don't let it bother you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually it doesn't, dad.  I knew when I chose a career in the public eye that I'd be open to certain criticisms, it's the price I pay for my celebrity.  Thank you, Niles, for bringing me the paper, and thank you for highlighting it in yellow!  Now, who would like some wine?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I'll have some.

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, this salad is exquisite.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sitting down:_] Now why would he say that?

speaker: Martin
text: Must be the carrots, he always did like them.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not the salad, Derek Mann.  I mean, why would he write a thing like that?  I've never done anything to him, the attack is totally unwarranted.  I'm a healer, for God's sake.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, for crying out loud!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I have every right to feel upset about this - I will not enjoy my dinner until this is where it belongs - in the trash.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, oh, there was an article in there I wanted to save.

speaker: Martin
text: On what?

speaker: Niles
text: Nothing.

speaker: Martin
text: Come on, I'm interested.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, let's drop it.

speaker: Martin
text: Why can't you tell me?

speaker: Niles
text: All right, it was all about Margaret Thatcher's secret for growing prize-winning zinnias.  Are you happy?

speaker: Martin
text: [_beat_] Not really.  **OH, YEAH...**  _Scene Two - Radio Station. The following afternoon Frasier is taking a call on air in his booth as Roz listens._

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Lorraine.  Now, calm down and try and listen to what I'm going to say to you.  Will you do that?

speaker: Lorraine
text: [_v.o:_] Okay.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, good girl.  Now your problem...

speaker: Lorraine
text: [_beep_] Oh my gosh, another call waiting - someone else is trying to get through.  Do you mind if I take it?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no.  Go right ahead. [_she does_] Well, certainly a very interesting situation she's got herself into.  Don't you think so, Roz?  _Roz is busy eating and reading magazines.  She has to quickly chew her food, put down her books just for the simple:_

speaker: Roz
text: Yes.

speaker: Lorraine
text: Okay, I'm back.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Lorraine.  Now listen very carefully to what I'm going to tell you.  Your problem seems...

speaker: Lorraine
text: [_beep_] Oh, I'm sorry, I'll be right back.

speaker: Frasier
text: For someone who's got so many problems she certainly is popular. [_laughs_]

speaker: Lorraine
text: Okay, go ahead Dr. Crane.  I'm here. [_beep_] Oh, I don't believe it - another call.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hold it there, Lorraine.  The reason why you want to take that other call is the same reason that you want to change your career and break up with your boyfriend.  You're obsessed with what you think you're missing.  The better offer, the call on the other line.  Well, you've got to take one call at a time from now on.  Fully explore and experience each one in its turn and you'll be a stronger person for it.  Do you follow me, Lorraine?

speaker: Lorraine
text: Okay, I'm back!

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you for your call. [_hangs up_] Well, we've only got two minutes left, so I would like to end today's program on a personal note.  As some of you may know, yesterday I was mentioned in Derek Mann's "Mann About Town" column.  He said, and I quote, "I Hate Frasier Crane"... "I Hate Frasier Crane". [_sarcastic:_] What trenchant criticism.  Move aside Voltaire, step back in the shadows H.L. Mencken, there's a new kid in town.  One can only wonder how many hours Derek Mann sat in the glow of his computer screen before his trembling fingers sprang to life and pecked out this chef t'ouerve: "I Hate Frasier Crane."  A lesser critic would have wasted our time by presenting a well thought-out, point by point, constructive critique of this show.  No, not our Mr. Mann.  So dear listeners, when Mr. Mann's column arrives on your front doorstep - read it, enjoy it, but above all, treasure it.  For one day this man will be joining the Pantheon of the immortals.  And if we're lucky... it'll be one day soon.  I'm Dr. Frasier Crane. [_signs off_]  _Frasier presses the off air button, and twirls his microphone around before blowing on it as if it were his weapon, then "holsters" it in his belt.  FADE TO:_  **YEAH!**  _Scene Three - Caf e Nervosa. The following afternoon Frasier is drinking a coffee in the cafe with Roz when Niles enters and sits with him._

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, how funny running into you here.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm always here.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes well, you weren't here twenty minutes ago: have you seen today's "Times"?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_knowing what's coming:_] No.

speaker: Niles
text: Lucky for you I saved you this copy.  Take a look at Derek Mann's column.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, this is the second time in as many days that you have given me a paper.  Have you ever considered getting yourself a route?

speaker: Niles
text: [_to Roz:_] Hello, I don't believe we've met.

speaker: Roz
text: Yes we have, Niles, three or four times.  Roz Doyle.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, of course.  It was at the... it was during the... well, I'm far too successful to feel awkward.  Where did we meet?

speaker: Roz
text: The radio station.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, I'll take your word for it.  Nice to see you again. [_then, to Frasier:_] Mr. Mann heard your program yesterday.

speaker: Frasier
text: So I see. [_reading:_] "Yesterday afternoon, Dr. Frasier Crane got on my case for not giving him a point by point criticism of his radio show.  Well, he asked for it, so here goes."

speaker: Roz
text: [_noticing:_] Oh my god, his entire column is about your show.

speaker: Niles
text: Not very flattering either.  Towards the end he even attacks your "dimwitted sidekick call screener."

speaker: Roz
text: [_appalled:_] That's me!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, now I remember you!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_reading:_] "It's hard to say what I hate most about Crane's show -- his pompous, sanctimonious style, his constant self- congratulatory references to his own life, or his voice: a mock- sympathetic tone so sickly sweet one wonders if the man graduated from medical school or from some mind-controlling cult."

speaker: Niles
text: It's continued on twelve.

speaker: Frasier
text: I've read enough!

speaker: Waiter
text: [_asking:_] Can I get you something?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Niles:_] How can the man think something like that?

speaker: Waiter
text: It's my job, I'm a waiter.

speaker: Frasier
text: We don't want anything, thank you.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, I know this stinks, but in a couple of days it'll blow over.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, perhaps you're right.  As angry as it makes me, to retaliate would be to stoop to his level.  So the best response is no response at all. _FADE TO:  Scene Four - Radio Station. Soon after these comments he is already shouting into his microphone about the recent newspaper report._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_angry:_] "Pompous and sanctimonious," am I?!  Well, this Mann character can't even write grammatical sentences!  Every five words there's one of his precious "dot, dot, dots." Must be because he likes writing all those dots with the crayon he writes this drivel in!  _Roz, who looks like she has been listening to him rant for quite a while, tries to steer him back to the show._

speaker: Roz
text: Dr. Crane, on line two we have Stewart who's having a problem with delayed gratification.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, he's just going to have to wait!  I don't know who this Derek Mann thinks he is, but if he thinks he can hide behind his newspaper like some sniveling schoolchild cowering behind a tree, then I say let's expose this Derek Mann for what he is: not a man at all, but half a man! [_to Roz:_] Now what line did you say Stewart was on?

speaker: Roz
text: He hung up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm leaving all sorts of bodies in my wake today. Let's see who's on line five. [_he presses button:_] Hello, this is Dr. Frasier Crane - I'm listening.

speaker: Derek
text: [_v.o:_] Good, because I was listening too.

speaker: Frasier
text: And you are?

speaker: Derek
text: Derek Mann.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_regretting:_] I see.

speaker: Derek
text: Look, nobody calls me half a man - especially some Ivy League twit.  So what do you say we settle this like men?

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you implying that you want to fight me?

speaker: Derek
text: I'm not implying, I'm saying.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fight, as in a fist fight?

speaker: Derek
text: [_sarcastic:_] No, I thought we might throw pies at each other!  So are you up to it, or aren't you man enough?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_thinks_] We'll be right back after these messages.  _Frasier signs off for commercials as we fade out.  End Of Act One. (Time: 11:05)  Act Two.  Scene One - Radio Station. The scene resumes where we left off.  The commercials have finished and Frasier gets back to his radio show._

speaker: Frasier
text: And we're back.  Well, we have a surprise caller on the line: Derek Mann.

speaker: Derek
text: [_v.o:_] So what's it going to be, Crane, are you going to fight me or not?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you can't be serious.

speaker: Derek
text: Just like I figured, you're chicken.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I just don't think that civilized people behave that way.  You know, Roz, perhaps our listeners have an opinion about that subject?  Who do we have on the line?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, lines one through eight are people who think you're chicken.

speaker: Derek
text: You're chicken, Crane.  Admit it!

speaker: Frasier
text: I am not chicken!

speaker: Derek
text: [_squawks like a chicken_]

speaker: Frasier
text: We are mature thinking people, not cavemen!

speaker: Derek
text: [_squawks some more_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright, if you want a fight so bad, I'll give you a fight! You just say the time and place!

speaker: Derek
text: Kinsley square, right outside your office, by the old statue.  Noon tomorrow.  Don't back out!

speaker: Frasier
text: I won't!  Don't you back out either because I know where your office is too, and I know where you live, and I'll track you down!  Now who else out there wants a piece of me?! **ET TU, EDDIE?**  _Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment. That evening Martin is searching through his old case as Daphne passes him._

speaker: Daphne
text: Having a look at that old murder case again?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I've dug out the old crime scene photos.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, don't be a greedy guts - let me have a look.  _Daphne has a look at the photo of the girl.  After a while her psychic powers kick in._

speaker: Daphne
text: Her name was Helen.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, it was. [_knowing her trick:_] Ah, you must have seen it on some of my papers I've had lying around here.

speaker: Daphne
text: No, I just got this feeling when I touched the picture.

speaker: Martin
text: You're putting me on.

speaker: Daphne
text: She had a lot of men in her life.

speaker: Martin
text: No kidding: she was a hooker!

speaker: Daphne
text: No, I mean she had four brothers.

speaker: Martin
text: [_surprised:_] That's amazing.  She did have four brothers. What else are you getting?  Well, come on, tell me more.

speaker: Daphne
text: I can't just turn it on and off like a faucet.

speaker: Martin
text: Give it a try, will you?  Please.  What else are you getting?

speaker: Daphne
text: Nothing. [_suddenly:_] No, wait.  I see a man.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah?

speaker: Daphne
text: A well-dressed man.  He's wearing wing tips and a trench coat.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah?  Yeah?

speaker: Daphne
text: He's getting off an elevator... he's walking down a long hallway... she doesn't know he's coming... he's opening the door...  _At this moment, a well-dressed man enters the apartment wearing wing tips and a trench coat - it's Frasier._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, everyone.

speaker: Daphne
text: Sometimes I get my signals crossed.

speaker: Frasier
text: What's going on?

speaker: Martin
text: Well - unless you killed a hooker when you were twelve - nothing much!

speaker: Daphne
text: We heard your show today.  I just loved the way you handled that Derek Mann.

speaker: Martin
text: You made your old man proud.  Yet the best part was when he challenged you to a fight and you stood right up to him.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_worried:_] Yes I did, didn't I?

speaker: Martin
text: I can't wait to see that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm not actually going to go through with it, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: What are you talking about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I already won our little war of words.  What would I stand to benefit by going through with actually going through with a fist fight?

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, maybe I'm misunderstanding here... he challenged you and you're backing down?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, mature people are supposed to use their intellect to settle their differences.

speaker: Martin
text: A man doesn't just turn his tail and run - that's not the way I brought you up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you encouraging me to fight?

speaker: Martin
text: You bet I am - you gave the guy your word.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but I didn't even know what I was saying - I hadn't even had lunch yet.

speaker: Martin
text: I might have known this would have happened.  It's Billy Kreizel all over again.

speaker: Frasier
text: What did you say?

speaker: Martin
text: Something about a Billy Kreizel, I believe.

speaker: Frasier
text: I can't believe you're dragging that up - that was thirty years ago.

speaker: Daphne
text: Who's this Billy Kreizel?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, he was this kid in fifth grade that used to torment me!

speaker: Martin
text: So one day Frasier made fun of Billy's crewcut.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, he started it by making fun of the elbow patches on my blazer!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, the point is, they were supposed to meet for a fight after school.  Only "Patches" here didn't show up!

speaker: Frasier
text: I had a clarinet lesson!

speaker: Martin
text: You don't need to remind me of that!  Billy's old man was a cop, too.  Boy, the guys rode me about that excuse of yours for years.  Every time I couldn't make it out for a drink they used to say, "What's the matter?  You got a clarinet lesson?"

speaker: Daphne
text: [_wondering:_] Couldn't you and Billy have met after the clarinet lesson?

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, would you please excuse us for a moment!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_gets up:_] I have a feeling I'm going to be excused quite a lot in this house.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sarcastic:_] Dad, I am sorry if I embarrassed you for not fighting Billy Kreizel thirty years ago.  But the situation is not the same now.

speaker: Martin
text: It's exactly the same.

speaker: Frasier
text: I am an adult now, I've been to medical school, I hold a certain position in this city - I do not settle my differences with brawling.

speaker: Martin
text: The man challenged you and you accepted.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I can't believe this.  You won't be happy until I come home with a black eye.

speaker: Martin
text: I just want you to do what you said you were going to do. You know, you can talk about your medical school, your intellect, your place in this city, but you know what?  It's all one big clarinet lesson... I can't even look at you.  _Martin exits to the kitchen, angry with his son.  Frasier is left with little dignity and looks at Eddie for a little support.  However, even Eddie turns his face away from him.  Frasier can only sulk._  [_N.B. Billy Kreizel is the name of a boy who bullied director David Lee in the sixth grade._] **REQUIEM FOR A LIGHTWEIGHT**  _Scene Three - Caf e Nervosa. The next day, Frasier is preparing for the big fight whilst chatting with Roz._

speaker: Roz
text: So, I step out of the shower, I look out of the window and I notice the garbage man looking right in at me.  So I say, "Did you get a good look?"  And he says, "Not completely, turn around."  Then he smiled, and he's missing a tooth, and that's when the romance went right out of it for me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, why are you telling me this story?

speaker: Roz
text: I'm trying to take your mind of the fact that in five minutes you're going to walk right out into that square and get your clock cleaned.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, has it ever occurred to you that I might actually win this fight?

speaker: Roz
text: Your shoe's untied. [_Frasier checks his tied shoes_] If you fell for that one, you're going down and you're going down hard.

speaker: Niles
text: [_enters_] Frasier, there's quite a crowd forming out there. Secretaries with bag lunches, business men, children with balloons...

speaker: Frasier
text: All that's missing is a mariachi band.

speaker: Niles
text: They're setting up.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I better go find a great place in the crowd.  I'll be off to the left, Frasier, for when you tear his ear off and want to throw it to a beautiful _senorita._

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, as your brother and as your friend - why are you doing this?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's Billy Kreizel.

speaker: Niles
text: [_looking around:_] Where?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shakes head_] He's not here, Niles.  It's just that I ran away from him when I was ten.

speaker: Niles
text: I remember.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I've been running ever since.  You know, this is where it stops.  I'm not running anymore.

speaker: Niles
text: What is it that makes us Crane boys such targets?  _As he says this, he takes his nail file out of his coat pocket and buffs his nails.  He blows on them and offers the file to Frasier which he refuses._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sarcastic:_] Chalk it up to random violence!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad?  What are you doing here?

speaker: Martin
text: Look son, I said a couple of things last night that maybe went over the line.

speaker: Frasier
text: Look dad, if you were worried that you talked me into something that I wasn't ready to do -- well, you're wrong. You can relax.  I took this on for myself.

speaker: Martin
text: Good.

speaker: Frasier
text: Who told you that I was going through with it, anyway?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, let's just say a father knows certain things about his son.

speaker: Daphne
text: Good news, I parked in front of a broken meter.  We're getting a freebie.  Well, good luck, Dr. Crane, with the fight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Daphne.  Any psychic predictions on the outcome?

speaker: Daphne
text: Actually, yes.  But don't worry, I'm frequently wrong.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, Frasier, there's something I want you to see. [_points out of window:_] There, the man standing to the left of the statue - I recognize his picture from the newspaper, that's Derek Mann.

speaker: Frasier
text: He's gigantic!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_looking out:_] My God, you could show a movie on his back!

speaker: Martin
text: Are you sure you want to go through with this?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes I am.

speaker: Martin
text: Good, you'll be fine.  Just remember this is a street fight and not a boxing match.  So fight dirty and throw the first punch!

speaker: Daphne
text: I found that a swift knee to the groin usually does the trick. [_cocky:_] If you have any doubts, check with a fellow in Manchester named Nigel Tavers.

speaker: Niles
text: [_begins to leave:_] Well, if we want an unobstructed view...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_stops him:_] Look, I prefer if you guys stay here.  You'll only make me nervous.

speaker: Martin
text: Whatever you want.  _They all wish Frasier good luck.  As he exits the mariachi band strikes up.  They all move over to the window to look out._

speaker: Martin
text: They've got a mariachi band out there!

speaker: Niles
text: I'll have to get their card, I need someone for our summer barbeque.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh look, they're starting the fight.

speaker: Martin
text: Nah, they're just circling, sizing each other up.  Come on, Frasier, if you're going to hit him, hit him now!

speaker: Niles
text: Is that the police?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, what are they doing here?

speaker: Daphne
text: They're breaking it up!  Just when they were getting started.  _Shouts are heard from the crowd hurling insults at the police force. The officer marches Frasier right into the Caf e._

speaker: Frasier
text: Alright, I'll come along peacefully - let me just get my jacket.

speaker: Officer
text: Relax, I'm not arresting you.  But I'm warning you that in this town we don't settle our differences with street fights - no matter who you are.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well thank you, officer, you'll have no more trouble from me.

speaker: Officer
text: Okay. [_exits_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, dad, did you see me?  My hands are trembling, my chest is pounding, my mouth is all dry, my knees are like jello... God, I feel great!

speaker: Martin
text: You did good.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, I was out there.  I was raring to go, you saw that...

speaker: Martin
text: I know you were.  You would have kicked his butt!

speaker: Daphne
text: From here to Tacoma.

speaker: Niles
text: [_shouting:_] I think we should celebrate!  Everyone, a round of victory lattes on me.

speaker: Martin
text: Thanks Harry, I owe you one.

speaker: Officer
text: No problem, Marty.

speaker: Martin
text: You cut it pretty close, though.  Another minute, then Frasier would have been sidewalk litter.  He would have been lunch meat.

speaker: Officer
text: Say, some of the guys are getting together later at Duke's. Why don't you come along?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, maybe I will.  And you know why I will?  Because the Crane boys don't take clarinet lessons anymore.

speaker: Officer
text: What the hell are you talking about?

speaker: Martin
text: [_embarrassed:_] Oh that's right, you weren't in my precinct.
